item.title: Neurophysiological investigation of listening effort and multilingual communication
item.description: Listening to a second language (L2) in real life situations (e.g., a noisy restaurant) can be challenging. Native listeners can flexibly modulate their speech processing to overcome the demands of a noisy environment e.g., use semantic-contextual information to understand what is being said. We know very little, however, about the strategies second-language listeners use to enhance their listening.
